articles.headline: Bill Promotes Universal College Loans
articles.snippet: After reports that some lenders have stopped offering federal loans at community colleges, two senators introduced legislation to forbid lenders from picking and choosing among institutions.
articles.abstract: After reports that some lenders have stopped offering federal loans at community colleges, two senators introduced legislation to forbid lenders from picking and choosing among institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Responding to reports that some lenders have stopped offering federal loans at community and other colleges, two Democratic senators introduced legislation Tuesday to prohibit lenders from picking and choosing among institutions.

articles.headline: MBIA Debt Is Setting Up a Quandary
articles.snippet: Credit default swaps are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.
articles.abstract: Credit default swaps are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: The risks associated with the vast, unregulated market for credit default swaps played a crucial role in the bailout of Bear Stearns. Now these financial instruments are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: At Least 51 Are Killed in Blast at Baghdad Market
articles.snippet: A car bomb exploded during the busiest time of day in a Shiite neighborhood. It was the deadliest attack in Baghdad in more than three months.
articles.abstract: A car bomb exploded during the busiest time of day in a Shiite neighborhood. It was the deadliest attack in Baghdad in more than three months.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Mudhafer al-Husaini and Ali Hameed, and written by Mr. Oppel.
articles.byline: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr., MUDHAFER AL-HUSAINI and ALI HAMID

articles.headline: Three Questions for McCain
articles.snippet: There are some unanswered questions about John McCain’s economic plans. And we in the media have largely overlooked those questions so far.
articles.abstract: There are some unanswered questions about John McCain’s economic plans. And we in the media have largely overlooked those questions so far.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week before Pennsylvania’s Democratic primary  in April, back when Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama were still the big story  John McCain traveled to Pittsburgh to remind everyone how different his economic agenda would be from theirs.

articles.headline: Investors Seek Asian Options to Costly China
articles.snippet: A number of multinationals are creating or expanding other Asian bases, particularly in Vietnam.
articles.abstract: A number of multinationals are creating or expanding other Asian bases, particularly in Vietnam.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOI  Canon is no longer building or expanding factories in China, but the company is doubling its work force at a printer factory outside Hanoi to 8,000.

articles.headline: At Social Site, Only the Businesslike Need Apply
articles.snippet: In the midst of Silicon Valley’s recession-proof enthusiasm for community-oriented Web sites, LinkedIn, the most boring of the social networks, is grabbing the spotlight.
articles.abstract: In the midst of Silicon Valley’s recession-proof enthusiasm for community-oriented Web sites, LinkedIn, the most boring of the social networks, is grabbing the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For a Web site, it could hardly look less exciting. Its pages are heavy with text, much of it a flat blue, and there are few photos and absolutely no videos.

articles.headline: Burmese Endure in Spite of Junta, Aid Workers Say
articles.snippet: Relief workers are offering a less pessimistic picture of the human cost of the delay in reaching cyclone survivors.
articles.abstract: Relief workers are offering a less pessimistic picture of the human cost of the delay in reaching cyclone survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar  More than six weeks have passed since Cyclone Nargis swept through the Irrawaddy Delta in southern Myanmar, leaving a trail of flattened villages and broken lives and arousing international sympathy that turned to anguish as the military government obstructed foreign aid.

articles.headline: After Attacks, Michelle Obama Looks for a New Introduction
articles.snippet: As her husband’s general election campaign gets into full swing, Mrs. Obama is getting a subtle makeover.
articles.abstract: As her husband’s general election campaign gets into full swing, Mrs. Obama is getting a subtle makeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama’s eyes flicker tentatively even as she offers a trained smile. As her campaign plane arcs over the Flathead Range in Montana, she is asked to consider her complicated public image.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Detroit’s Shrinking Sales Take a Toll on Dealerships
articles.snippet: Decades of declining market share have left Detroit automakers with too many stores and too few customers.
articles.abstract: Decades of declining market share have left Detroit automakers with too many stores and too few customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  In the glory days of Detroit carmakers in the 1960s, Leonard J. Immke Jr. used to sell 200 new Buicks a month from his vast downtown showroom here filled with gleaming Electras, Rivieras and Skylarks.
